metadata.title: High throughput and comprehensive approach to develop multiepitope vaccine against minacious COVID-19 2 Rupal Ojha 1# , Nidhi Running Title-Multi-epitope vaccine against COVID-19

abstract.text: The ongoing enigmatic COVID-19 outbreak, first reported from Wuhan, China, on last day of 26 the year 2019, which has spread to 213 countries, territories/areas till 28 th April, 2020, 27 threatens hundreds of thousands human souls. This devastating viral infection has stimulated 28 the urgent development of viable vaccine against COVID-19 across the research institutes 29 around the globe. The World Health Organization (WHO) has also confirmed that the recent 30 pandemic is causing Public Health Emergency of International apprehension. Moreover, the 31 earlier two pathogenic SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV and many others yet to be identified pose 32 a universal menace. Here, in this piece of work, we have utilized an in silico structural 33 biology and advanced immunoinformatic strategies to devise a multi-epitope subunit vaccine 34 against ongoing COVID-19 infection. The engineered vaccine sequence is adjuvanted with ß-35 3 defensin and comprised of B-cell epitopes, HTL epitopes and CTL epitopes. This is very 36 likely that the vaccine will be able to elicit the strong immune response. Further, specific 37 binding of the engineered vaccine and immune cell receptor TLR3 was estimated by 38 molecular interaction studies. Strong interaction in the binding groove as well as good 39 docking scores affirmed the stringency of engineered vaccine. The interaction is stable with 40 minimal deviation in root-mean square deviation and root-mean-square fluctuation was 41 confirmed by the molecular dynamics simulation experiment. The immune-simulation by C-42 ImmSim server, which mimics the natural immune environment, yielded more potent 43 immune response data of B-cells, Th cells, Tc cells and IgG for vaccine. The encouraging 44 data obtained from the various in-silico works indicated this vaccine as an effective 45 therapeutic against COVID-19.

46 47 48 49 647 thankful to the Central University of Rajasthan for providing computational facility 648 Competing financial interests: The authors have declared no competing interest 649 650 651 652 653 654 655

body_text.text: Hypothetically, almost all proteins of the miniature organism (viruses) are potential vaccine 116 targets (Shi et al., 2015) . In an incredibly fast piece of study, it has been shown that once this 117 virus installed itself into the human body, it encodes its "tool proteins" which helps in the 118 replication. These "tool proteins" i.e. non-structural proteins are the key (toolkit) to 119 synthesize the other structural proteins (Spike, Membrane, Envelope and Nucleocapsid) and 120 factors which requires to grow its progeny (Lewis et al., 2020) . In our strategy of vaccine 121 development, we have engineered the toolkit i.e. non-structural proteins which includes 3-C 122 like proteinase (YP_009725301.1), RNA dependent RNA polymerase (YP_009725307.1), 123 Helicase (YP_009725308.1), 3'-5' exonuclease (YP_009725309.1), 2'-O-ribo methyl 124 transferase (YP_009725311.1) & endoRNase (YP_009725310.1). All these proteins have 125 also used as a drug target for commercially available antiviral drugs to fight against sudden 126 outbreak of COVID-19, since there are no specific antivirals available (Beck et al., 2020) . 127 Further, several non-structural proteins make the replicase-transcriptase complex, which 128 ultimately helps in the replication and transcription of virus genomic RNA (Ziebuhr, 2005) .
The 3-C like proteinase is a protease present in all coronaviruses, which helps in proteolysis 130 of the non-structural protein 5 (nsp5) during replication process of virus (Tomar et al., 2015) .

This makes it a high value vaccine candidate against the coronavirus. Further, a key enzyme 132 of coronavirus replication and transcription system is RNA-dependent RNA polymerase 133 (RdRp), which is encoded by nsp12, also appears as an attractive target for therapeutics (Gao Prediction of Cytotoxic T Lymphocytes (CTL) epitopes for vaccine designing 185 The CTL epitopes for vaccine designing were predicted by using NetCTL 1.2 server 186 (http://www.cbs.dtu.dk/services/NetCTL/). This server comprises of two datasets, one is of 187 HIV (human immunodeficiency virus) CTL epitopes and other one is their source proteins.
The proteins present in the datasets have been cleaved into all probable 9 mers. The exception 189 was only for the annotated epitopes and the remaining ones are considered as non-epitopes.

The protein sequences in FASTA has been required as input for the prediction of potential Apart from this, the average antigenic propensity of the designed vaccine candidate was Grand average of hydropathicity (GRAVY) 0.060 candidate was probably non-allergen and will not lead to any allergy during pre and post 454 vaccination. Subsequently, with the help of ToxinPred server we have checked the toxicity of 455 the epitopes, as this server accepts the protein sequences of >500 amino acids and here, in 456 this study the designed vaccine candidate was of 561 amino acid. So, after doing this it was 457 found that all the epitopes involved in the designing of vaccine candidate was non-toxic and 458 will not release any toxic components after administration (Supplementary table-5A, 5B and   459 5C). This above data suggested that the designed vaccine candidate was highly stable, RaptorX server.

Tertiary structure refinement and validation 485 The tertiary structure refinement was achieved with the help of 3D refine server. As an output 486 the server generated five refined models and the selection of best model was done on the 487 basis of various parameters. The model number fifth was selected as its 3D refine score was 488 40460.5 which was less than all the other four models. Additionally, the GDT-TS score of the 489 selected model was 0.9960 whereas the GDT-HA score was 0.9501, these higher scores 490 denotes the conservative refinement. Next, the RMSD (root mean square deviation) was 491 0.450, this higher score indicates the aggressive refinement in comparison to initial non-492 refined one. The MolProbity score was 3.790 and the RWPlus (potential energy) score was - The score obtained by QMEAN4 server was -7.25 whereas the global IDDT score of the 501 model was 0.9182 (this score should be ranges between 0 and 1). Next, with the help of 502 QMEANDisCo scoring function we have predicted the global quality of model, the obtained 503 global score was 0.35 ± 0.05. This data suggested that the score (global, local, IDDT) 504 obtained for our model structure was higher and in between the range, hence, we can 505 conclude that designed model has best scoring and was of exceptional quality (Figure-4) . reported that mice lacking TLR3 and TLR4 are more vulnerable to SARS-CoV in 540 comparison to mice having TLR3 and TLR4 receptors; exceptionally weight loss was 541 observed when exposed to infection, but no mortality was detected (Totura et al., 2015) . One immune receptor TLR-3 using HADDOCK server. The immune simulation experiment was performed using C-ImmSim server which, gives a 595 real immune response result. In our results, we have observed the proliferation in secondary 596 and tertian immune response which is identified by IgG1 + IgG2 and IgM. Also, while 597 decreasing the antigen count IgG + IgM also showed the proliferated response in Figure 8 A.
Result revealed the immune response development upon immunization. B-cell population 599 level was also stimulated and seems to be very high upon immunization (Figure 8 B) .

FIGREF0.text: for latest ongoing respiratory infection outbreak, which started in late 2019 in 52 Wuhan, Hubei, China (Huang et al., 2020). Its first case was reported in late November, 53 2019. Coronavirus belongs to Coronaviridae family and is an enveloped, non-segmented 54 virus, which possess positive sense RNA as a genomic material. This particular outbreak is 55 thought to be correlated with a crowded seafood market in Wuhan, China, which has been 56 closed since 23 January 2020. Several investigation teams are working for the identification 57 of origin of the spread. By April 28, 2020, there are 2,954,222 (~ 3 million) confirmed cases 58 of COVID-19 globally out of them 84,341 were from China, mainland and ~4,643 deaths 59 have been attributed, reported by WHO. Outside China mainland, there are reports that 213 60 other countries/territories around the globe are affected with highest cases recorded in 61 European region which has crossed 1.3 million (1,359,380) confirmed cases and 124,525 62 claimed lives followed by Regions of Americas which has 11,405,20 confirmed cases of 63 COVID-19 and 58,492 claimed lives (WHO Situation Report 98). There are several host 64 where Coronavirus infections have been reported such as avian hosts (Zhu et al., 2020), 65 mammals like dogs, cats, camels, mice masked palm civets and bats. Reports has been shown 66 the identification of novel mammalian coronaviruses now almost on regular basis. For 67 instance, Coronavirus named HKU2 was originated from bat in 2018 and infected the pigs, 68 which further showed the fatal diarrhoea syndrome (https://www.who.int/docs/default-69 source/coronaviruse/situation-reports/20200305-sitrep-45-covid-19.pdf?sfvrsn=ed2ba78b_2).

FIGREF1.text: Spread of already known human coronaviruses is not so threatening i.e. they have shown only 71 mild clinical symptoms(Cavanagh, 2007). While two evident exclusions are Severe Acute72 Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) coronavirus and Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) 73 coronavirus in 21 st Century means in last two decades. SARS-CoV belongs to genera 74 Betacoronaviruses that originated from Guangdong Province in Southern part of China in 75 year 2002 (Ismail et al., 2003), which unfortunately claimed 774 human lives and >8,000 76 infections in human from 37 countries around the globe in 2002 to 2003 (Zhou et al., 2018). 77 Another outbreak, MERS-CoV was started from Saudi Arab in 2012 (Zhou et al., 2018) and 78 2494 infection cases of MERS-CoV were reported as laboratory confirmed cases with 858 79 fatal cases from 2012 to date which includes claim of 38 lives (Su et al., 2016). Past two 80 outbreaks and a recent ongoing outbreak may only be a fraction of what yet to come or can be 81 seen and understood i.e. more severe and possibly new zoonotic infections of coronaviruses 82 incidences yet to be discovered which shows a worldwide warning to public health (Peiris et 83 al., 2004). 84 Researchers are trying to solve the enigma of the origin of the SARS-CoV-2. As per 85 evolutionary virologist, it is rarely possible the direct jump of the virus from bat to human 86 there should be one connecting link between them. Now, the puzzle is which animal worked 87 as a transient host from bats to humans. Recent announcement but those studies still have not 88 published, revealed an intermediate candidate i.e. Pangolins as transient host. 89 A high mortality rate of the past incidences shows the imperative need of the successful 90 vaccine candidate, which can ultimately lead to the prevention of such outbreaks. The best 91 way to overcome with the present situation and also preparedness for the upcoming outbreaks 92 is the development of the vaccine against this deadly COVID-19. Particularly, in the absence 93 of any effective drug treatment against these deadly viruses, vaccines are considered to be an 94 obligate requirement. The continuous spread of this devastating viral infection with high 95 mortality rate demands a protected and efficient vaccine. In modern times, multi-epitope 96 subunit vaccine (MESV) formulation is newest way to fight against deadly pathogens.

FIGREF2.text: Epitopes (Cytotoxic T Lymphocyte (CTL), Helper T Lymphocytes (HTL) and B-cell98 Lymphocytes (BCL) i.e. short stretches of amino acid sequences of protein can elicits direct 99 and strong immune response, then response generated by whole protein itself (Kao et al., 100 2009). Nevertheless, for the development of the MESV, amino acid sequence of the 101 immunogenic proteins of interest should be known. Scientist working in Chinese Center for 102 Disease control and Prevention & National Institute for Viral Disease and Prevention in 103 Beijing, China and their associate collaborators emancipated whole genome sequence of 104 COVID-19 and shared on all public databases, demonstrating fast sequencing of genome in 105 the response of devastating outbreak which is helping in better diagnosing and treatment of 106 further incidences. Upon initial analyses, sequencing data revealed the homology at protein 107 sequence level with SARS-CoV and might latches onto human angiotensin-converting 108 enzyme 2 (ACE2) receptor (Chan-Yeung and Yu, 2003). 109 Developing vaccine against COVID-19 is very challenging, since research to develop a 110 vaccine against earlier coronaviruses outbreaks like SARS and MERS, generated only limited 111 responses (Zumla et al., 2019). The past research work was more attentive on the viral Spike 112 (S) glycoprotein and receptor binding domain (RBD) of this glycoprotein (Shi et al., 2015).

FIGREF3.text: But those strategies are now giving us the jumping off points for the development of vaccine 114 against deadly novel COVID-19.

FIGREF5.text: 134 et al., 2020). This enzyme catalyses the viral RNA synthesis and therefore plays an important 135 role in the replication/transcription process during COVID-19 infection. Helicase of 136 coronavirus encodes by nsp13 helps in the parting of dsDNA and RNA in a 5' -3' direction 137 (Adedeji and Lazarus, 2016). Endoribonuclease is an enzyme encoded by nsp15, which 138 cleaves specially at uridine residues and another replicative enzyme that is exoribonuclease 139 encoded by nsp14 possess the N7-methyltransferase activity and also involved in checking 140 fidelity of the replication whereas nsp16 encodes for 2'-O-ribo methyl transferases. 141 Remarkably, nsp14 and nsp15, both ribonucleases are distinct to Nidovirales order which are 142 envisaged genetic markers for the viruses belongs to this order (Bhardwaj et al., 2004; Snijder 143 et al., 2003). However, a recent insilico study has anticipated that several non-structural 144 proteins work as adhesins, which plays role in the adhesion and invasion into the host cell 145 (Ong et al., 2020). Hence, these tool proteins, which makes the replication/transcription 146 machinery complex, and also function as adhesins could be good candidate for vaccine 147 development. To develop a strong and potential vaccine, we have used an immunoinformatic 148 approach and also shown its binding with the human immune receptor TLR-3 by molecular 149 interaction studies. The strategy we have used helped in identifying the antigenic epitopes for 150 all proteins used in the study and vaccine construct was analysed for several other parameters 151 like antigenicity, allergenicity, physicochemical properties which is suited as a candidate 152 vaccine. The strategy used in the study has shown in the figure 1.

FIGREF6.text: Schematic flow of the transmission of recent outbreak COVID-19 and work flow 155 used in the designing of vaccine candidate against menacious coronavirus (COVIDselection from SARS-Cov-2 proteome for vaccine designing 163 In the current study, we have selected the non-structural proteins of SARS-Cov-2 which is 164 the responsible for the pandemic, COVID-19. The sequences of the proteins were retrieved ://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/) in the FASTA format. The details of proteins along with 167 their accession numbers and functions has been given in introduction section. After the 168 sequence retrieval, all the sequences were individually to subjected to pBLAST server 169 (https://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi?PAGE=Proteins) to check the homology of the 170 selected viral proteins with human proteome. Next step was to check the antigenicity of each 171 protein and this was done with the help of ANTIGENpro protein antigenicity prediction 172 server which is a part of Scratch protein predicter (http://scratch.proteomics.ics.uci.edu/).

FIGREF7.text: Prediction of Helper T Lymphocytes (HTL) epitopes for vaccine designing174    After the selection of protein sequences, we have predicted the HTL epitopes from each175 protein with the help of Immune epitope database and analysis resource, IEDB 176 (https://www.iedb.org) server. This freely available online server encompasses the 177 experimentally validated data of all the species (animals and humans) on B-cell and T-cell 178 epitopes perspective to infectious diseases (Vita et al., 2015). For the HTL epitope prediction, 179 the selected protein sequences were given as input in FASTA format. The selection of allele 180was done for the human and the full HLA reference set was selected in order to obtain the 181 epitopes prevalent to any geographical region.

FIGREF9.text: epitopes. By using neural networks and weight matrix-based system, the server predicted the 192 MHC I binding efficiency of epitopes, proteasomal cleavage sites (C terminal) and TAP 193 transport efficiency. Next, the identification of epitopes was constrained to 12 supertypes,194 which are known to enumerate the variance in binding specificities with MHC I class 195 molecules (Larsen et al., 2007). 196 Prediction of B-Lymphocytes epitopes for vaccine designing 197 B-cell epitopes in this study have been predicted via ABCpred server 198 (http://crdd.osdd.net/raghava/abcpred/). This highly cited and reliable server utilizes machine 199 learning algorithm and artificial neural network (ANN) for the epitope prediction from 200 antigenic sequence. The datasets present in this server contains around 700 B-cell as well as 201 700 non-B-cell epitopes, having maximum length of 20 amino acids, but it also has the option 202 of selecting the length for predicted epitope (10, 12, 14, 16 and 20 amino acids length) (Saha 203 and Raghava, 2007). As per recurrent neural network the server has the accuracy of 65.93%. 204 Here, we have given the protein sequence as input and set the other parameters threshold 205 (0.51) and overlapping filter (ON) as default except for amino acid window length which was 206 set as 10.

FIGREF10.text: selected epitopes were combined together with the help of linkers or spacer sequence 210 of amino acids. Different linkers have been used to link the B-cell, HTL and CTL epitopes 211 for instance KK linker was used for making B-cell epitope combinations while AAY and 212 GPGPG were used for CTL and HTL epitope joining. Next, the adjuvant at the starting of 213 sequence (N-terminal) was added and then to link the adjuvant epitopes one more linker was 214 used i.e. EAAAK linker. After joining all the adjuvant, linkers and epitopes in a sequential215    manner, a single potential vaccine candidate was generated.216Physiochemical properties, antigenicity, allergenicity and toxicity prediction217    The physiochemical properties of the designed COVID-19 vaccine construct was predicted 218 with the help of ProtParam-an ExPASy server (https://web.expasy.org/protparam/). This 219 server computes the various parameters of protein sequence which includes theoretical pI, 220 molecular weight, estimated half-life, extension coefficient, instability index, aliphatic and 221 GRAVY index.222For the prediction of antigenicity of the designed construct, ANTIGENpro server 223 (http://scratch.proteomics.ics.uci.edu), share of Scratch protein predictor, was utilized. This is 224 the first server which predicted antigenicity of the entire protein by using experimental 225 proven microarray analysis reactivity data meant for five pathogens. This server predicts the 226 antigenicity of protein on the basis of alignment free and manner. It is a sequence based, 227 pathogen independent server whose predictions are made by five machine learning228 algorithms and further the antigenic or non-antigenic nature of the protein get finalized by 229 SVM (Support Vector Machine) classifier.230 Further, the allergenicity of the vaccine candidate was predicted by an online server namely 231 Algpred (http://crdd.osdd.net/raghava/algpred/) and AllerTop (https://www.ddg-232 pharmfac.net/AllerTOP/) servers. The AlagPred server predicts the allergenicity on the basis 233 of matching of vaccine sequence against the known epitope sequences (Saha and Raghava, 234 2006) whereas the AllerTop server utilizes the machine learning techniques which are 235 inclusive of DT (Decision tree), kNN (k nearest neighbours), LR (Logistic regression), MLP 236 (Multilayer perceptron) NB (naïve Bayes), RF (Random forest) but among them the five-fold 237 cross validation was only showed by the kNN method with the maximum precision of 85.http://crdd.osdd.net/raghava/toxinpred/) was used to predict the toxicity of the designed 240 vaccine candidate. This tool predicts the toxicity of peptides as well as entire protein 241 sequences and accepts the input in fast format and then work on score of position specific 242 basis of Quantitative Matrix, which further identifies the toxicity of the submitted sequence 243 (Gupta et al., 2015). http://raptorx.uchicago.edu/StructPredV2/predict/). The server compares the input sequence 247 with other nonredundant homologs in order to evaluate the quality of model and then on this 248 basis generates the 3D structure accordingly. RaptorX server graded second and it works by 249 utilizing CNF (conditional neural fields), CRF (conditional random field) and MTT (multiple 250 template threading) which assimilate various biological signals and convert them into a 251 plausible nonlinear scoring function (Källberg et al., 2014). 252 Tertiary structure (3D) refinement, model quality assessment and validation 253 The refinement of the obtained tertiary structure was done with the help of 3D protein 254 structure refinement server (http://sysbio.rnet.missouri.edu/3Drefine/). This CSAP (Critical 255 Assessment of protein Structure Prediction) evaluated server is freely available and demands 256 either the initial structure or protein sequence as input in order to perform the statistical and 257 graphical analysis. The server utilizes complete physics and intelligence-based force fields to 258 perform the frequentative optimization of hydrogen bonds and energy minimization 259 (Bhattacharya et al., 2016). 260 After refinement of the 3D structure, the quality of model was again verified with the ://swissmodel.expasy.org/qmean/). The QMEAN server evaluates the global and local 263 quality of the structure. As input the server requires a 3D model in PDB format or sequence 264 of the protein. Before proceeding to the submit option, user can choose scoring function as 265 per their requirement, there are three QMEAN scoring functions-1. QMEAN 2. 266 QMEANDisco 3. QMEANBrane. The complex QMEAN scoring function includes two 267 subtypes QMEAN4 and QMEAN6 which estimates the quality of complete structure and also 268 for each amino acid by using single PDB model. The second one is QMEANDISCO, this also 269 perform the same function as QMEAN does, except calculating the pairwise distance 270 constraints (DisCo) between each amino acid residues. The last one is QMEANBrane, this 271 only evaluates the local quality of models, especially for membrane proteins and also show 272 the membrane, soluble, interface and transmembrane part of the input PDB model (Benkert et 273 al., 2009). 274 At last, after the structure modelling, refinement and quantitative energy analysis its 275 validation is a very decisive part. For the validation purpose, we have utilized RAMPAGE 276 server (http://mordred.bioc.cam.ac.uk/~rapper/rampage.php). As an input the server requires 277 the PDB structure on protein and then utilizes the quantum mechanics to predict the favoured, 278 allowed and disallowed regions. The prediction was done on the basis of phi vs psi backbone 279 angles, steric clashes, hydrogen bond energy, planarity of peptide bonds (Lovell et al., 2003). ://milou.science.uu.nl/services/HADDOCK2.2/haddockserver-easy.html). This server 284 utilized both biochemical bioinformatics and biophysical methods information to improve 285 sampling and scoring of docking results. As an input the server requires the active and 286 passive residues from both the receptor and ligand as well as their energy minimized PDB 287 models. These interactive residues firstly, predicted with the help of CPROT server and then 288 used in HADDOCK. The server provides the output on the basis of van der Waals energy, Z 289 score, desolvation energy, RMSD score, etc., in which the Z-score represents the estimation 290 of standard deviation (De Vries et al., 2010). 291 Molecular dynamics simulation of designed vaccine candidate and TLR-3 receptor 292 For the dynamical simulation of designed vaccine candidate and TLR-3 receptor, in this 293 study, we have utilized GROMACS (GROningen MAchine for Chemical Simulations) v5.0 294 programme with the force field GROMOS96 43A1. This works on the command lines and 295 after the run of program, trajectory files were generated which is a time taken process but 296 defines the motion of all the atoms over the time (Abraham et al., 2015; Ojha et al., 2020; 297 Van Der Spoel et al., 2005). Before starting the first step in GROMACS all the HOH atoms 298 were get removed via PYMOL software and then input the PDB file to start the first module 299 of GROMACS as pdb2gmx. After this the topology file of the input protein was generated 300 which have all the specifics about bonded and non-bonded interaction or features. After this 301 the next step was of solvation, with the help of commands the protein get centred in a box of 302 1.0 nm, which was then filled with the solvent (can be water or any other solvent). Further, 303 the ions (Na or Cl ions) were added in the solvation box, having the charged protein, in order 304 to exchange the HOH molecules with it. Then, prior to MD run, energy minimization of the 305 protein was done to achieve the lowest energy of the protein. Subsequently, the equilibration 306 of the solvent was done in association with pressure (NPT) and temperature (NVT). After the 307 stabilization of pressure and temperature ensembles, the final MD simulation ran for 10ns to 308 positively produce the trajectory files, which defines the microscopic movement of the 309 system. 310 Immune dynamics simulation of the designed COVID-19 vaccine candidate 311 In this study, we have performed an in silico experiment which generates the immune-312 response for vaccine candidate. There is an online dynamic immune simulation server https://www.iac.cnr.it/~filippo/projects/c-immsim-online.html) (Rapin et al., 2010) which 315 uses the sequence of vaccine candidate as an input. The advanced C-ImmSim server, which is 316 consistent with earlier version uses the amino acid strings in place of Bit strings. As per the 317 literature, dose interval of 1 month is prescribed for immunization of vaccine, though there 318 are some vaccines where the difference can be 2, 3 or 6 months between first immunization 319 and first booster dose. Thus, we had chosen the one-month interval and identified the dose 320 dependent immunological response of our vaccine candidate. Besides, the likeliness of the 321 immune response generated by the vaccine (in response to pathogen invasion) was analyzed 322through repeated exposure of X following injection doses. In each instance, one dose was 323 made up of X vaccine molecules where the simulation was conducted for almost X days.324Finally, the immune response generated was calculated in the form of Simpson Index (D).

FIGREF11.text: general, proteome of the SARS-CoV-2 has both structural and non-structural proteins and 332 after literature survey we came across this point that the non-structural proteins of virus are 333 mainly responsible for their replication in host(Ojha et al., 2019a). Here, in this study we334    have targeted "toolkit" of the virus i.e. the non-structural proteins for vaccine designing.335    Recently, researchers have reported the study about multi-epitope vaccine against the novel336    coronavirus and in that, they have targeted the structural protein of coronavirus whereas in 337 our current study we have selected the non-structural proteins as they have also been reported338    as key or potential antiviral drug targets. So, targeting the already reported drug targets for 339 vaccine designing purpose will be more effective. Further, as per recent survey report, it was 340 found that SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV both belongs to the same beta coronavirus group 341 with the 70% similarity between their genomes (Cheng and Shan, 2020). So, targeting the 342 replication machinery proteins of this deadly coronavirus for vaccine designing could be a 343 better way to block the expansion of disease either its SARS or COVID-19.344For the development of immunogenic vaccine, we have proceeded by retrieving all 345 the six key proteins from NCBI database. Apart from this, by using pBLAST server we have346 checked the homology of all the viral protein with human proteome. With this process we 347 came to conclusion that none of the viral protein was showing any kind of sequence 348 identity/similarity with the human proteins expect, helicase protein. The helicase protein was 349 showing 22.4% of identity and 34% query coverage with the ZGRF1 isoforms proteins of 350 homo sapiens, but as per Pearson William (2013) (Pearson, 2013), for the purpose of vaccine 351 designing the sequence similarity between the human and pathogen should not be more than 352 40% in order to overcome the probabilities of cross reactivity. Here, with this data we can 353 conclude that the non-structural proteins used for vaccine designing will show no cross-354 reactivity reactions when administered in host. Also, we have checked the antigenicity of all 355 the selected non-structural proteins with the help of ANTIGENpro server. The result 356 indicates that the all the proteins were highly antigenic in nature and their sequences can be 357 utilized for the purpose of vaccine designing (Supplementary Table-1). 358 Antigenic B-cell epitopes prediction from the COVID-19 proteome 359 B-cell epitope prediction was done via ABCPred server and the obtained epitopes were then 360 finalized on the basis of their ranking and highest score. The epitopes with highest score have 361 the highest binding affinity. A total six B-cell epitopes were selected (one from each protein 362 sequence) with the length of 10 mer amino acid each (Supplementary table 1). 363 Antigenic MHC class II epitopes prediction from the COVID-19 proteome 364 This study has utilized the most reliable and validated immunoinformatic servers for the 365 prediction of antigenic epitopes (B-cell, HTL and CTL) which are probably conserved across 366 the diverse coronavirus species and expected to recognize the human T-cell and B-cell 367 receptors in order to generate a potential immune response against the COVID-19. The 368 immunoinformatic servers provides an easiest way, which curtails the experimental effort for 369 the epitope identification. In the field of vaccinology, many researchers with the help of 370 reverse vaccinology approach have proved the antigenicity of peptide vaccines in 371 contradiction of various infectious diseases (Dikhit et al., 2017; Muruato et al., 2017; Ojha et 372 al., 2018; Pandey et al., 2019).373For the identification of antigenic HTL epitopes from all the protein sequences, IEDB 374 server was utilized. The epitopes were sorted on the basis on percentile rank which was less 375 than or equal to 0.9 and IC 50 value, less than or equal to 50. The lowest percentile rank and IC50 value denotes good binding affinity of epitopes with the HLA (Human leucocyte 377 antigen). The next criteria, selection of allele, was done on the basis of distribution of 378 population in the COVID-19 endemic regions. In the current study, we have tried to cover 379 almost all regions in which COVID-19 confirmed cases were reported and total 12 epitopes 380 were selected i.e. two epitopes from each protein sequence Alleles according to their 381 frequency and geographical region has been mentioned inFigure 2. The IC 50 value and the 382 percentile rank score of each epitope has been given separately in supplementary file as table Graphical representation of predicted HTL epitopes along with their percentile 385 rank and HLA distribution.386 Antigenic MHC class I epitopes prediction from the COVID-19 proteome 387 The CTL epitopes were predicted via NetCTL server and at the time of prediction all the 388 parameters were set to default for instance, C-terminal cleavage (0.15), threshold value important for the effective and specified recognition of T-cell epitopes from 391 many viral diseases for instance HIV, MMR, MERS, SARS etc. The supertype selection in 392 this study was done according to the percentage of worldwide population coverage. With the 393 help of literature survey, we came across that the supertypes A2, A3 and B7 together covers 394 around 88% population globally (Sette and Sidney, 1999; Shen et al., 2018). A total of 18 395 epitopes were selected; three from each protein sequence (Supplementary table 3).396 Designing of COVID-19 multi-epitope antigenic vaccine candidate 397 After the prediction of all antigenic vaccine candidates, they were joined with each other with 398 the help of linkers in order to generate a single construct. However, in multi-epitope vaccine 399 each epitope should have the capability to induce the potential immune response and for that 400 linkers are the main factor which are involved in locating the epitopes as well as responsible 401 for the immunogenicity of the entire construct. They are also use to discrete the domains, in a 402 single protein sequence without distressing the function of protein and helps to maintain a 403 stable and flexible protein complex. Here, in this study we have used different types of 404 linkers to connect the epitopes for instance, for linking B-cell epitopes "KK" (Yano et al., 405 2005) (augmentation of proteasome processing) linkers were used while for linking CTL and 406 HTL epitopes "AAY" (Ojha et al., 2019b) (proteasomal cleavage site and avoid the genesis 407 of new epitope) and "GPGPG (Livingston et al., 2002) (for improving the flexibility of 408 protein)" linkers were availed, respectively. Along with these linkers one more linker was 409 used i.e. EAAAK, which has been reported as a helix forming linker in the designing of next-410 generation vaccine. Next, to acquire more immunogenic construct, at the N-terminal of the 411 designed vaccine an adjuvant namely, human beta defensin 3 (45 amino acids) was attached. 412 This TLR-3 agonist human beta defensin 3 has been well known to augment the strong T-cell 413 and B-cell immunity (Gupta et al., 2020; Mohan et al., 2013). 414 After linking of all the epitopes, a single immunogenic vaccine candidate of 561 amino acids 415 was created. Here, we have designed the vaccine candidate in this sequential manner-416 Adjuvant-B-cell-HTL-CTL. In the vaccine sequence, the former 45 amino acids were 417 occupied by an adjuvant, next 6 amino acids were of EAAAK linker and then from number 418 51-120 amino acids were covered by B-cell epitopes whereas 121-345 and 346-561 were 419 obscured by HTL and CTL epitopes, respectively (Supplementary figure 1). 420 Assessment of physiochemical properties, antigenicity, allergenicity and toxicity of 421 designed COVID-19 vaccine candidate 422 The physiochemical properties were computed on the basis of certain parameters such as 423 instability index which was 26.9, (should be less than 40) hence, showing the stable nature of 424 the vaccine candidate. Next, on the basis of N-terminal residue (N-end rule), half-life of the 425 protein was estimated (on models like yeast and E. coli in vivo, mammalian reticulocytes in 426 vitro), which denotes that after the synthesis of protein in cell, at what time partial amount of 427 the protein will get dissipate? As per result, we have found that the estimated half-life for the 428 designed vaccine candidate was >30 hours and hence, inversely demonstrating that designed 429 vaccine candidate was stale in nature. The calculated GRAVY (Grand average of 430 hydropathicity) score was 0.060 and this positive score specifies the highly hydrophobic 431 nature of protein. Next, the aliphatic index of the protein epitomizes the space reserved by 432 aliphatic side chains (AVIL) and the calculated score was 81.99, the higher aliphatic index 433 denotes highly stable side chains of the protein. Other calculated parameters have been shown 434 in

FIGREF12.text: , which represents the highly antigenic nature of the vaccine. According to the 442 AntigenPro server, high score signifies the more antigenic nature of the protein. For the 443 antigenicity prediction AlgPred server was used and the result obtained from this server was 444 based on the 6 approaches (IgE mapping, MEME/Mast motif, SVM modules based on both 445 amino acid and dipeptide composition, BLAST search on ARPs and combined approach or 446 hybrid approach which involves all the parameters). Among these 6 approaches, SVM 447 modules based on both amino acid and dipeptide composition and Hybrid approach identified 448 the vaccine construct as allergenic whereas MEME/Mast motif, BLAST search on ARPs, IgE 449 mapping approaches identified the construct as non-allergenic. So, further to cross check this 450 mystery we again checked the allergenicity with AllerTop server, the result from this server 451 exposed the designed vaccine construct as probable non-allergen. Hence, by taking both the 452 results from different servers into consideration, we concluded that designed vaccine 453

FIGREF13.text: antigenic, probable non-allergic and non-toxic in nature.461 Structure prediction and model quality assessment of the designed COVID-19 vaccine 462 candidate 463Tertiary structure of the designed vaccine candidate was achieved via RaptorX server. The 464 tertiary structure of the vaccine candidate was predicted as 2 domains-domain 1 and domain 465 2 and the best template with id-5cwmA was generated and the calculated p-value for the 466 model was 4.31*10^-04. The p value represents the quality of the predicted model or 467 structure and value less than 10^-3 is a signal of good quality of model. It was also found that 468 all the residues (100%) of the sequence were modelled and the percentage of disordered 469 region was zero. Next calculated parameters are of percentage composition of coil, helix and 470 beta strands which was 47%, 16% and 35%, respectively (Tertiary structure prediction of designed vaccine candidate with the help of 483

FIGREF14.text: both lower scores indicate the best quality of model. 494 After refinement, the quantitative model energy assessment was done with help of 495 QMEAN server. For the estimation of local and global quality of model we have assessed the 496 same by using all the three scoring function options available in QMEAN server, as described 497 in methodology. The refined 3D model was given as input and the first estimation was done 498 for QMEAN4 scoring function which evaluates the global and local model quality as well as 499global IDDT score which is the local distance difference test between per amino acid residue.

FIGREF16.text: (A) Refined tertiary structure, refined with the help of 3D refine server. (B and D) 509 Showing the Z score and model quality (C) Showing the membrane insertion energy of the 510 refined protein structure.511Subsequently, the validation of the refined model was done via RAMPAGE 512 server which predicted the φ (phi) and ψ (psi) torsion angles of the residues. The Ramachandran Plot assessment provides us the information about the backbone, 514 sidechain and geometry of C alpha conformations. Firstly, we have done the 515 analysis of the non-refined vaccine 3D structure and we have found that the 516 favoured region covered 431 residues (77.1%) while the number of residues in 517 the allowed region was 82 (14.7%) and for the disallowed region was 46 (8.2%)Fig.5 A)Secondly, we have generated the Ramachandran Plot for the refined 3D 519 vaccine structure(Fig.3) and the graphical representation has showed that the 520 around 461 residues were in the favou red region (82.5%), whereas 64 (11.4%) 521 and 34 (6.1%) amino acid residues were in allowed and disallowed area of the 522 protein sequence, respectively(Fig.5). This data suggested that the refined 523 vaccine candidate has more stability and flexibility in compari son to non-refined 524 one. However, the best quality model in RAMPAGE should have ~98% residues 525 (expected) in the most favoured region so, here we can conclude that the score 526 obtained for the refined 3D model was good then the non -refined one but not the Ramachandran plot shoeing the differences between the (A) non-refined and (B) 534 refined protein tertiary structures.535Molecular docking or protein-protein interaction of the COVID-19 and TLR-3 receptor536    In this study, we have selected TLR-3 receptor for carrying out docking with the designed537 vaccine candidate (COVID-19). The role of TLR-3 has already been known in the previous 538 studies of SARS coronavirus infection. During the SARS outbreak in 2015 Tortura et al. has539

FIGREF17.text: Molecular interaction studies of vaccine candidate with immune receptor TLR3 score versus interface-RMSD, (C) HADDOCK score versus fraction of 564 frequent contacts (FCC), (D) Vanderwaals energy versus interface-RMSD, (E) Electrostatic 565 energy of interacted complex versus interface-RMSD. 566 Molecular dynamics simulation of the docked complex 567 For the accomplishment of highly stable vaccine candidate we have performed the in silico 568 simulation of the docked complex (vaccine candidate and TLR-3 receptor) with the help of 569 GROMACS. Various steps like energy minimization, pressure assessment, temperature, and 570 potential energy calculations were analyzed after the MD simulation study. The temperature 571 calculation plot reveal that the system remains persistent at 300 K (Fig. 7A) at around 100 ps 572 time interval, whereas in case of pressure the system demonstrates pressure fluctuation with 573 an average value of 1 bar at the same time interval (Fig. 7B). The complex root mean square 574 deviation (RMSD) plot demonstrated the structural stability and flexibility of the docked 575 complex. RMSD vs. time plot reveals that the primary fluctuation started with 0.15 nm and 576 completed at 0.55 nm after 6 ns of a time span and the minor fluctuations were also observed 577 in the docked complex, after this the complex reached to its stable position at 6 ns (Fig. 7C). 578 Next, the root medium square fluctuation (RMSF) was obtained for amino acid side chains in 579 order to analyse the fluctuations of amino acid in the docked complex. The RMSF plot 580 reveals minor shifts in amino acid side chains, indicating the continuing interaction of the 581 vaccine candidate and the TLR-3 receptor. In the RMSF plot the very fluctuated regions 582 indicates the extremely flexible complex and here, the higher peaks (100-200 residues and 583 600-700 residue) in the RMSF plot indicate approximately 0.4 nm suggests that the complex 584 comprises extremely stable extents (Fig. 7D). 585 The figure showing the results of molecular dynamics simulation of vaccine and 587 immune receptor TLR3 using GROMACS. A and B showing the equilibration phase 588 ensembles-temperature (constant at 300k for 100ps) and pressure (displaying fluctuations at 1 589 bar value for 100ps), respectively. (C) RMSD (root mean square deviation) plots reflects the 590 stability between the vaccine candidate and TLR-3 receptor whereas (D) RMSF (root mean 591 square fluctuation) reflecting the flexibility and fluctuation of the amino-acids residues in the 592 side chain of docked complex. 593 Generation of Immune response by COVID-19 vaccine candidate 594

FIGREF18.text: Likewise, in secondary and tertian immune response, cell mediated immunity i.e. the601 cytotoxic and helper T cells (Tc & Th) levels were high (Figure 8 C & D). Level of IFN-γ 602 was retained during the exposure time which has been shown in Figure 8 E. These results are 603 significant for the immune response against SARS-CoV-2. Hence, the designed vaccine 604 candidate can compete to control the devastating coronavirus outbreak. Immune Simulation results by C-ImmSim: an in silico experiment of the 608 engineered vaccine candidate. (A) represents the antigen injection and proliferation of 609 immune response by immunoglobulin production. Various sub-classes of immunoglobulin 610 are represented as colored peaks. (B) The active B-cell population is observed on the 611 administration of vaccine. (C) The illustration of the generation of Helper-T cells, and (D) 612 The illustration of the generation of cyototoxic-T cells after the vaccine administration. In the 613 graphs, RESTING indicates to the cells, which were not shown to the antigens while 614 ANERGIC indicates the tolerance level of antigen. (E) Graph showing the induced cytokine 615 level upon administration of vaccine. The inset graph indicating the Simpson Index, D of IL-616 2. Simpson Index, D was inferred as the measurement of diversity. to be known about the COVID-19, which is spreading through China and claiming 620 thousands of lives. Featuring the effect of this debilitating outbreak is not feasible because of 621 its rapid spread. The recent three outbreaks of coronaviruses in past two decades are different 622 from their "common cold" causing friends and can spark a fire in individual's body. The 623 newly dubbed enemy, in the form of virus was initially named as COVID-19 by World 624 Health Organization (WHO) and now formally named as SARS-CoV-2. The virus primarily 625 attacks on respiratory system, which involves three major steps: replication of the virus, 626 hyper-reactivity of the immune system and pulmonary obstruction. As per the WHO, the 627 virus makes the perforated holes in the lungs, which upon infection give them honey-comb 628 appearance. To inhibit the viral infections in human the vaccination is one of the most 629 desirable way. Herein, we have devised a multi-epitope subunit vaccine to elicit the immune 630 response against COVID-19 which comprises of an adjuvant i.e. beta-defensin 3 at N 631 terminal end followed by B-cell epitopes, HTL epitopes and CTL epitopes connected with 632 appropriate linker sequences. The physicochemical parameters of vaccine candidate which 633 includes allergenicity, solubility, pI, hydrophobicity, molecular weight, GRAVY, half-life 634 indicated its effectiveness. The binding specificity of the vaccine candidate with human 635 immune cell receptor i.e. TLR3 was assessed by molecular docking interaction. Lowest 636 energy score obtained showed the strong interaction and specificity between vaccine and 637 binding groove of TLR3 receptor. Our devised vaccine candidate showed the stable and 638 prolonged binding in molecular dynamics simulation with negligible deviation in RMSF and 639 RMSD values. Additionally, immune simulation that mimics the natural environment in 640 computational immunology experiment exhibited the strong immunological response data 641 from the major players of the immunity i.e. cell mediated (T-cell) and humoral (B-cell) at 642 different doses at different intervals for COVID-19 multi-epitope subunit vaccine. This work 643 provides an innovative vaccine construct against the recent COVID-19 outbreak and 644 encourages the development of the vaccine against other newly emerging infectious disease.

Here, we have selected the first best complex of cluster number 1 because the Z score (denotes standard deviations) of the selected complex was -1.0 which was lowest among all obtained clusters, the lowest score always designates the highest binding capacity (Figure 6).
